policy_name: Academic Integrity and AI: Policy Guidance for Students

scope.jurisdiction: University of Cambridge and constituent colleges

preamble: Cambridge's commitment to academic excellence requires that assessed work demonstrates your own knowledge, understanding, and intellectual effort. While AI tools offer valuable learning opportunities, their use must be transparent, appropriate, and in line with assignment requirements.
fundamental_principles: Your work must be distinctly your own
All material sources, including AI, must be acknowledged
AI use must comply with specific assignment instructions
You remain ultimately responsible for accuracy and integrity of submitted work

permitted_applications.description: Using AI to enhance comprehension of difficult concepts
permitted_applications.permitted_in: General learning (not assessed work unless approved)
examples: Using ChatGPT to explain quantum mechanics concepts
Using AI to explore alternative proofs in mathematics
Using AI to work through practice problems for understanding
permitted_applications.disclosure_requirement: Not required for private learning; recommended in assessed work

permitted_applications.description: Using AI to identify, summarize, and organize academic sources
permitted_applications.permitted_in: Theses, essays, literature reviews (with tutor approval)
examples: Using AI to organize bibliography
Using AI to identify relevant research areas
Using AI to summarize key findings from papers

permitted_applications.description: Using AI for grammar, style, and structural improvements
permitted_applications.permitted_in: All written work with appropriate disclosure
examples: Using Grammarly for proofreading
Using AI to improve clarity of explanation
Using AI to refine argument structure
permitted_applications.disclosure_requirement: Yes, if substantive (more than grammar checking)

permitted_applications.description: Using AI as learning tool for programming and technical skills
examples: Using GitHub Copilot with code review
Using AI to learn new programming paradigms
Using AI to understand algorithms
permitted_applications.disclosure_requirement: Yes, in code comments or submission statement

permitted_applications.description: Using AI tools for statistical analysis and visualization
examples: Using AI to suggest statistical approaches
Using AI to generate publication-ready visualizations
Using AI to check calculations

impermissible_practices.definition: Presenting AI output as original human work without disclosure
examples: Copy-pasting ChatGPT essay without acknowledgment
Submitting AI-generated analysis as your thinking
Presenting AI-written sections without marking them as such
impermissible_practices.consequences: Disciplinary hearing, module failure, academic exclusion

impermissible_practices.definition: Using AI when explicitly prohibited by assignment guidelines
examples: Using generative AI on examination paper (exam halls explicitly AI-free zones)
Using AI on assignment marked 'individual work only'
Using AI to avoid learning core module competencies
impermissible_practices.consequences: Zero on assignment, possible course failure

impermissible_practices.definition: Using AI to fabricate data, evidence, or citations
examples: Generating fake experimental results
Creating non-existent scholarly sources
Inventing quotations attributed to authors
impermissible_practices.consequences: Suspension or expulsion, potential legal action

impermissible_practices.definition: Claiming AI understanding or skill you don't possess
examples: Submitting AI-written code claiming to understand it
Using AI analysis without verifying correctness
Relying on AI to bypass learning requirements

disclosure_statement_format.title: AI Use Declaration
required_information: Tool name and version (e.g., ChatGPT-4, GitHub Copilot v1.88)
Purpose of use (brainstorming, code generation, proofreading, etc.)
Extent of use (entire document, specific sections, iterative refinement, etc.)
Modifications made (what you changed, verified, or improved)
disclosure_statement_format.example: AI Use Declaration: ChatGPT-4 (OpenAI) was used in January 2025 to generate initial structure for this literature review. All AI-generated content was reviewed for accuracy, substantially modified to include my analysis, and verified against source materials. The critical synthesis and conclusions are entirely my own work.

before_term: Communicate your college and departmental AI policies clearly
Provide examples of acceptable and unacceptable AI use
Establish expectations for disclosure and documentation
during_supervision: Discuss AI use openly during progress meetings
Monitor for patterns suggesting inappropriate use
when_reviewing_work: Look for sudden changes in writing quality or technical complexity
Compare current work to previous submissions
Note inconsistencies between AI-likely content and demonstrated understanding
Request clarification if AI use is suspected but not disclosed
detection_and_response: Interview student about their work and process
Conduct viva voce if misconduct is suspected
Document concerns and follow formal procedures

department_implementation.requirement: Each department must publish subject-specific AI guidance
must_address: Whether AI is permitted in different assessment types
Specific disclosure requirements for the discipline
Penalties for misuse in your subject area
examples_provided: Essay-based subjects: Focus on originality of analysis
STEM subjects: Emphasis on understanding and verification
Practical subjects: Skills development must be genuine

misconduct_procedures.initial_concern: Report to college tutor or department director
misconduct_procedures.investigation: Formal misconduct hearing follows Cambridge regulations
misconduct_procedures.appeal: Right to appeal through established procedures
misconduct_procedures.support: Student support services available throughout process

key_messages: AI is a tool; you are the author and responsibility holder
Transparency about AI use is better than attempted concealment
Learning outcomes must still be achieved through your effort
Ambiguity should be resolved in favor of disclosure
